data.title: Some water in mountains
data.solution:
solution = 'simple'
if solution == 'simple':
    # Simple solution (quadractic complexity)
    w = int(input())
    L = [*map(int, input().split())]
    V = 0
    # For each column
    for i,h in enumerate(L):
        # Get the lowest border
        H = min(max(L[:(i+1)]), max(L[i:]))
        if H > h: # if we are in a hole (surrounded by higher borders)
            V += H - h # Add the column of water
    print(V)
elif solution == 'short':
    # Suggestion for short Python solution (100 characters)
    I=input
    I();L=[*map(int,I().split())]
    I(sum(min(max(L[:i+1]),max(L[i:]))-h for i,h in enumerate(L)))
elif solution == 'optimal':
    # Optimal solution (linear complexity)
    # not needed for CoC, but still useful to know
    w = int(input())
    L = [*map(int, input().split())]
    # Precompute maximum for left borders
    ML = [0]*w
    for i in range(w):
        ML[i] = L[i] if i == 0 else max(L[i],ML[i-1])
    # Precompute maximum for right borders
    MR = [0]*w
    for i in range(w-1,-1,-1):
        MR[i] = L[i] if i == w-1 else max(L[i],MR[i+1])
    V = 0
    # For each column
    for i,h in enumerate(L):
        # Get the lowest border
        H = min(ML[i], MR[i])
        if H > h: # if we are in a hole (surrounded by higher borders)
            V += H - h # Add the column of water
    print(V)
data.statement:
You are studying the natural water supplies in a mountain. You've got a height map of the mountain which doesn't include the water levels of the lakes.
A lake results from the accumulation of the rain in a hole. From the height map, you want to compute how much water is accumulated in lakes.

The height map is given as a list of heights along the horizontal axis.
This height map...
1 2 3 3 2 1 1 2 3 3 4 4 6 7 5 4 3 3 3 3 3 4 3 3 3 1 2 4 6 6 5 5 4 3 2 1
... represents this mountain...
`             #
            ##              ##
            ###             ####
          ######     #     ######
  ##    #################  #######
 ####  ################## #########
####################################
123321123344675433333433312466554321`... which will be filled of water as below:
`             #
            ##~~~~~~~~~~~~~~##
            ###~~~~~~~~~~~~~####
          ######~~~~~#~~~~~######
  ##~~~~#################~~#######
 ####~~##################~#########
####################################`The result will then be the number of '~': 46

Beyond the limits of the height map, the height can be considered null, so that it cannot contain water.

<<TIP:>> You should consider computing the volume column by column to get a solution simple enough. Don't overcomplicate the problem !

testCases.title: Multiple simple holes on border Validator

data.stubGenerator:
read w:int
loopline w h:int
write Number of units of water in holes

INPUT
w: Width 
h: Height of the mountain at column i
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Width [[w]] of the height map (number of columns)
<<Line 2:>> The height map described by a list of [[w]] integers separated by spaces.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> Number of units filled of water
